subject: RE: [junit] Re: How to test error handling?
msgSnippet: ... And yet another possibility: Try EasyMock (www.easymock.org) which allows to define mock behaviour for interfaces without implementing a mock class.
messageBody:
> > From: Tung Wai Yip [mailto:tungwaiyip@...]
> >
> > But this would add clutter to the code. Mock object seems
> > cleaner. However, ResultSet is a large interface to implement.
>
> In addition to other good comments people have offered, I wanted to add
> that
> implementing all the methods in an interface, no matter how many, is a
> one-click operation in many IDEs these days. In Eclipse, for example, I
> right click on an class that I want to implement an interface and choose
> Override/Implement Methods, and voila!

And yet another possibility: Try EasyMock (www.easymock.org) which allows to
define mock behaviour for interfaces without implementing a mock class.

Johannes
